title: 103_s38
content: The Act is named the "Reform of Federal Intervention in State Proceedings Act of 1993." It amends Section 2244 of title 28, United States Code, regarding claims raised in State proceedings for a writ of habeas corpus. If a claim was not raised properly in State proceedings and resulted in actual prejudice, it can only be entertained if the failure was due to State action violating the Constitution or laws of the United States, or if the Federal right asserted was newly recognized by the Supreme Court after the procedural default. The Act, named the "Reform of Federal Intervention in State Proceedings Act of 1993," amends Section 2244 of title 28, United States Code, regarding claims raised in State proceedings for a writ of habeas corpus. A one-year limitation period applies to habeas corpus applications by individuals in State custody, running from the latest of several specified times. This includes when State remedies are exhausted, when impediments created by State action violating the Constitution or laws of the United States are removed, or when a Federal right newly recognized by the Supreme Court after a procedural default is asserted. The Act, titled the "Reform of Federal Intervention in State Proceedings Act of 1993," amends Section 2253 of title 28, United States Code, regarding appeals in habeas corpus proceedings. It states that final orders in such proceedings can be appealed to the court of appeals for the circuit where the proceeding took place. There is no right of appeal in cases testing the validity of a warrant for transferring a person charged with a crime to another district for trial. The Act amends Section 2253 of title 28, United States Code, allowing appeals in habeas corpus proceedings to the court of appeals for the circuit where the proceeding occurred. No appeal is permitted in cases challenging the validity of a warrant for transferring a criminal defendant to another district for trial. Rule 22 pertains to habeas corpus and Sec. 2255 proceedings. An application for a writ of habeas corpus must be made to the appropriate district court. If denied, the proper remedy is to appeal to the court of appeals. In habeas corpus cases arising from State court process, an appeal requires a certificate of probable cause from a circuit judge. Section 2254 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to streamline the process for appeals in habeas corpus cases from State court judgments. A certificate of probable cause is not required for appeals by the State or government. The amendment to Section 2254 of title 28, United States Code, simplifies the appeals process for habeas corpus cases from State court judgments. It states that a person in custody must exhaust State court remedies before being granted relief, and presumes factual determinations made by State courts to be correct in habeas corpus proceedings. The amendment to Section 2255 of title 28, United States Code, sets forth requirements for raising claims in habeas corpus motions, emphasizing the need to follow Federal rules of procedure and demonstrating actual prejudice resulting from the alleged denial of rights. The amendment to Section 2255 of title 28, United States Code establishes conditions for raising claims in habeas corpus motions, requiring adherence to Federal procedural rules and showing actual harm from the alleged rights violation. The two-year limitation period for filing a motion under this section starts from the final judgment of conviction or when governmental actions impede the motion. The amendment to Section 2255 of title 28, United States Code allows for the removal of claims created by governmental action in violation of the Constitution or laws, when the movant was prevented from making a motion. It also specifies the timeframes for raising claims, including when a right is newly recognized by the Supreme Court and retroactively applicable, or when the factual basis of the claim could have been discovered through reasonable diligence.
